Description: A terracotta head of the Egyptian Hermes, broken from a flask and probably of bust form. The head is beardless, with tightly curled hair; within the hair, above the temples, are small wings, and a lotus petal is set over the brow. The mouth of the flask, with a carinated profile and two small handles, rises from the top of the head. Made in a two-piece, or possibly three-piece, mould. Orange-brown Nile silt, with many white inclusions which have caused much spalling of the surface. Brown slip overall. Probably related to Memphis Black Ware.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Perhaps found in the Fayum. Ptolemaic, second or first century BC. Bibliog. Hayes 1997: pl. vi, left.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3336)
Hayes 1997 / Handbook of Mediterranean Roman pottery (pl.VI)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
